items.title: Gene-edited pigs deemed safe to eat by Health Canada
items.summary_auto: Food made from pigs engineered to be resistant to a porcine virus are as safe and nutritious to eat as pork currently on the market, Health Canada said Friday.

items.title: 2 dead after U.S. strike on alleged drug boat in Eastern Pacific
items.summary_auto: The U.S. military said Friday that it has carried out a deadly strike on a vessel accused of trafficking drugs in the Eastern Pacific Ocean, the first known attack since the raid that captured Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro earlier this month.

items.title: Keeping an eye on the far side of the moon
items.summary_auto: While human missions to the moon will be facing Earth, on the other side of the moon, completely hidden from view, there will be a plethora of robots silently peering out to the edge of the universe and back to find out how it all began.

items.title: Quebec revamps its coat of arms, removes British crown
items.summary_auto: The Quebec government announced Friday that it's removing the British crown from the province's official coat of arms, in what it described as a reaffirmation of the province's autonomy.

items.title: Trump's 'Board of Peace' gets its legitimacy from the UN, an agency he routinely belittles
My life as Hilary Duff. No, not that one
items.summary_auto: Sharing a name with a celebrity is equal parts comedic, exasperating and revealing for Hilary Duff, who is a writer and photographer in Canada.

items.title: Dozens of clergy arrested at anti-ICE protest near Minneapolis airport
items.summary_auto: Local police arrested dozens of clergy members who sang hymns and prayed as they knelt on a road at Minneapolis-Saint Paul International Airport, as part of a day of protest on Friday against U.S. President Donald Trump's deployment of thousands of immigration enforcement officers in the Twin ​Cities region.

items.title: B.C. mom with Stage 4 cancer says months-long wait to see oncologist put her at risk
items.summary_auto: A Port Moody, B.C., mother of two says she had to wait three months after being diagnosed with breast cancer to see an oncologist. She worries that wait has cost her precious time. B.C. Cancer data shows that while wait times are improving, British Columbia continues to lag behind other provinces.

items.title: Disgraced Winnipeg police officer sentenced to 7 years in prison 'believed he was untouchable'
items.summary_auto: Former Winnipeg police officer Elston Bostock was sentenced to seven years in prison on Friday, after pleading guilty to a long list of crimes that include selling drugs to friends and other officers and corruption offences.

items.title: 'You cannot rewrite history': Minister rebuffs Trump's claims about allies in Afghanistan
items.summary_auto: Finance Minister François-Philippe Champagne pushed back against U.S. President Donald Trump's latest comments about America's allies in Afghanistan as an attempt to rewrite the history books.

items.title: OMG! People are saying it's so cold trees will explode. That viral claim may be overblown
items.summary_auto: We're not even one month into 2026, and with everything that's happening, now we have to deal with exploding trees? No, not entirely. But a sudden deep freeze is going to send temperatures plummeting in much of Canada and the U.S., which could cause an ear-splitting phenomenon.

items.title: N.B. report finds herbicides, heavy metals not the cause of 'most' undiagnosed neurological illnesses
items.summary_auto: Environmental substances like herbicides and heavy metals are likely not causing the neurological symptoms reported by hundreds of New Brunswickers, an investigation by the province into the so-called mystery brain illness has concluded.

items.title: Send us your questions about the extreme cold in your area
items.summary_auto: Do you have a question about extreme cold in your area? Send an email to ask@cbc.ca.

items.title: Russia shows no sign of compromise as delegations meet in Abu Dhabi
items.summary_auto: Delegations from the U.S., Ukraine and Russia are meeting in Abu Dhabi for trilateral talks on ending the war.

items.title: Province releases final report on mystery neurological illness
items.summary_auto: New Brunswick's chief medical officer of health will release findings on Friday from an investigation into cases of undiagnosed neurological illness.

items.title: Closure of Porter Airlines crew bases to affect 60 pilots in Thunder Bay, Ont., and Halifax, N.S.
items.summary_auto: The upcoming closures of Porter Airlines’ crew bases in Thunder Bay, Ont., and Halifax, N.S., will affect 60 pilots, according to the Air Line Pilots Association (ALPA). Here's what we know about what this means for employees at the airline.

items.title: Trump cabinet member weighs in on Alberta separatism
items.summary_auto: U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent commented Thursday on the separatist movement in Alberta — making him the highest-ranking member of the Trump administration to weigh in on the province's politics.

items.title: First Nations chiefs demand answers over Alberta pipeline deal that doesn't mention water
items.summary_auto: Some First Nations chiefs are demanding answers from Ottawa after the federal government signed a pipeline agreement with Alberta that failed to make any mention of water consumption.

items.title: Brrr! Why a polar vortex is causing extreme cold in Canada
Stars, fans arrive in Rome for fashion icon Valentino's funeral
items.summary_auto: Global fashion celebrities joined the public on Friday morning to say goodbye to iconic designer Valentino at his funeral service in Rome, at the Basilica di Santa Maria degli Angeli e dei Martiri.

items.title: Decision reserved for Regina police officer who targeted 33 women using internal databases
items.summary_auto: A joint submission from the Crown and defence proposes a two-year suspended sentence to be served in the community, followed by three years of probation.

items.title: Canadian fugitive Ryan Wedding arrested after a decade on the run
'We can't wake him up': 911 call played as proceedings wrap for trial of couple charged in boy’s death
Ontario hospitals are cutting costs amid deficits, but say 'there are no easy choices left'
items.summary_auto: Ontario hospitals have already started making some "lower risk" cuts in the face of rising deficits, but those alone won't alleviate hospitals' financial strain, said the association head.

items.title: Climbers say 'it's just nuts' as Alex Honnold prepares to ascend skyscraper on livestream
items.summary_auto: Rock climber Alex Honnold's attempt to climb Taiwan's tallest skyscraper with no safety gear is likely to be a nail-biter, drawing millions of viewers around the world on Friday. While some rock climbing enthusiasts in London, Ont., say they'll tune in, they will be watching with a sense of both curiosity and anxiety.

items.title: More than 5,000 killed in recent protests in Iran, rights group says, as regime rejects Trump claims
items.summary_auto: Iran's top prosecutor on Friday called U.S. President Donald Trump's repeated claims that he halted the hangings of 800 detained protesters there "completely false." Meanwhile, the overall death toll from a bloody crackdown on nationwide demonstrations rose to at least 5,002, activists said.

items.title: Black bear ordered moved by Banff National Park leadership against wildlife experts' advice
items.summary_auto: A Banff National Park superintendent told Parks Canada wildlife staff — over their objections — to move a black bear due to public safety concerns at a popular resort ski resort, according to documents obtained by CBC News.

items.title: Young B.C. woman found dead on Australia beach likely drowned, autopsy finds
items.summary_auto: The Canadian tourist who was found dead on a beach in Australia earlier this week surrounded by a pack of dingoes likely drowned, according to preliminary autopsy results.

items.title: Kashechewan First Nation opens mobile clinic to help evacuees
items.summary_auto: A corporation majority-owned by Kashechewan First Nation has set up a mobile clinic in Kapuskasing, Ont., to provide medical care for evacuees in that city.

items.title: Samples from Manitoba bird die-off test positive for H5N1, but researcher says that offers some relief
items.summary_auto: The highly contagious H5N1 strain of bird flu has been found in samples collected in Manitoba after a die-off, but a U of Manitoba researcher says it's reassuring to know the virus hasn't mutated into a different strain.

items.title: Ottawa suggests opening sandhill crane hunting in northern Ontario
items.summary_auto: The federal government is considering putting sandhill cranes back on the menu in northern Ontario, potentially as early as this fall.

items.title: Uncertainty looms as federal cuts hit N.S. research farm
items.summary_auto: Staff at an Agriculture Agri-Food Canada research farm in Nappan, N.S., were given notice of cuts on Thursday, and the federal government is offering few details on the facility's future.

items.title: How grocery giants control who can sell food in your neighbourhood
Black boys missing from the Greater Toronto Area are being groomed by gangs to deal drugs far from home
Union says federal public service job cuts are going to be 'like the Hunger Games'
items.summary_auto: As the federal government seeks to downsize the public service, civil servants are weighing buyouts, early retirement packages and a process allowing them to trade jobs with someone exiting a position.

items.title: Inspectors visited Montreal building weeks before fire that shut down Jacques-Cartier Bridge
items.summary_auto: The vacant building that caught fire earlier this week in Montreal, forcing the closure of the Jacques-Cartier Bridge, was handed two infraction notices in recent years.

items.title: How Thunder Bay, Ont., is looking to give this south side neighbourhood new life
items.summary_auto: Located in historic Fort William, Thunder Bay's Simpson Street has been going through a lot of changes. The road itself has undergone massive repairs over the last couple of years, and the city is eyeing vacant buildings there for new development. Here's how different people are working to revitalize the neighbourhood on the northwestern Ontario city's south side.

items.title: As the Gulf of St. Lawrence warms, whales are switching up the menu and may be sharing lunch
items.summary_auto: New Canadian research, using decades of samples from the Gulf of St. Lawrence, shows that as Arctic krill becomes scarce, fin and minke whales are eating more of the kinds of fish that humpback whales eat — but that they’re sharing these resources

items.title: Searching for Ontario’s missing Black boys
items.summary_auto: Teenaged Black boys from the Greater Toronto Area, groomed into the illegal drug trade by adult criminals, are being sent to remote communities into Ontario’s north,  putting them in danger, an investigation by the fifth estate found.

items.title: Chris Pratt's Mercy is absurdly stupid AI propaganda
items.summary_auto: Mercy tells a seemingly topical, cautionary tale about our own immediate future. But following a man put on trial by an AI judge, it's also idiotic and out of touch.
